entry.title: SAP BTP Learning
entry.content:
Hello, I'm not new to the Community but I have an interest in building a Learning Journey for myself to prepare for "SAP Certification Associate: Positioning SAP Business Technology Platform As Part of Business Suite." I need to know where to start in my journey to gaining knowledge (training) to prepare for the exam within the next 3-4 months. Finally, I'm not technical but functional;-). 

Thank you in advance, Tina

entry.title: Error in SAP Mobile Services and Cloud Connector without main propagation
entry.content:
Hi community,

I'm facing a persistent issue with SAP Mobile Services and SAP Cloud Connector.

üìå Scenario:

  • I have a mobile application configured in SAP Mobile Services.

  • The destination points to an on-premise system via Cloud Connector.

  • Destination configuration:

    • Type: Cloud Connector

    • Authentication: Basic Authentication

    • User propagation: Disabled

  • In the mobile app:

    • Security is configured as OAuth (via XSUAA)

‚ùó Problem:

Even though authentication is set to Basic and principal propagation is disabled, Cloud Connector keeps logging the following warning repeatedly:

The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.

This happens every time the mobile app calls the destination.

‚ùì Question:

How can I prevent SAP Mobile Services from sending the SSO (Bearer) token when using a destination with Basic Authentication?
Is there any way to force SAP Mobile Services not to send the OAuth token, even if the app is secured with OAuth?

Any help or experience from someone who has solved this in a similar scenario would be greatly appreciated.

Destination: 

Cloud connector:

 

Logs:

2025-06-11 08:47:03,615 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x79d8e706#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:03,944 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0xf425f394#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:04,459 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0xc45ba802#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:10,583 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x043ba202#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:13,150 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x836b866c#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:14,072 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x62a66969#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:21,714 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x09a22876#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:21,933 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x26fd940c#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:23,808 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x58380bba#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: How to Configure SFTP Authentication in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) ‚Äì A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
SFTP Configuration and Usage Guide

 

* Access the SFTP Platform

  • Visit the URL:https://sftpcloud.io/tools/free-sftp-server
  • Click on the Login button located at the top right corner.

* Sign Up / Log In

  • Use the 'Sign Up / Log In' option to register or enter your account.

* Create SFTP instance

  • After a successful login, To Create New SFTP instance.

  • Next, Open the SFTP instance, click on 'Users', and then go to 'Connection Details‚Äô.

After configure SFTP server, we will have some info of it as

  • User name
  • Password phrase
  • Host name
  • SFTP Port

* Install WinSCP

  • Visit the URL:https://winscp.net/eng/download.php
  • Open WinSCP and login using the Host Name, User Name, and Password from the SFTP server.

  • Here, we create a directory or file in WinSCP to upload or download files from the SFTP server.

* Create Known Host in CPI
  1. Go to integration Suite Application
  2. Go to Design integration flow
  3. Go to Monitor item in left menu
  4. Go to Connectivity Test

  • Open Notepad, paste the Host Key, and save the file with an appropriate name (e.g., hostkey.txt).
  • Add this known host into CPI

* Create User Credentials

  1. Go to integration Suite Application
  2. Go to Design integration flow
  3. Go to Monitor item in left menu
  4. Go to Security Material
  5. Click on create

* To check the user credentials, go to 'Connectivity Test' and click on 'SSH'.

1. Username/Password :-

 

  • SFTP SENDER IFLOW

     Create/Configure an Integration Flow

  1. We are using HTTPS to send the data {\"productIdentifier\":\"HT-2000\"} because this value needs to be passed to the OData service.

  1. The JSON to XML Converter is used to convert incoming JSON data into XML, as required by the OData service.

  1. Use the Content Modifier to assign information to headers.

  1. Use the Request-Reply step to fetch product details from the OData service.

  1. The OData service is being accessed from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub (api.sap.com).

In the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, navigate to APIs ‚Üí ODATA V2, then search for 'Product Master'.

 Click on "Show API Key" to get the key needed for authentication.

In the API Specification, you can download the OData EDMX, which is useful when integrating in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) for OData service modeling.

In the Configuration Details section, the Sandbox URL helps in forming the complete endpoint URL by replacing the {host} placeholder with the actual hostname when configuring the OData connection in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI).

  1. Now in the connection, use the Sandbox URL as the Address.

We are using the data {\"productIdentifier\":\"HT-2000\"} to retrieve the specific product details from the OData service.

  1. Next, use the XML to CSV Converter to send data to the receiver, as the SFTP server only accepts CSV format.
  2. The SFTP Adapter is configured at the receiver end to deliver the converted CSV file.The directory and address are taken from the SFTP server, the file name is created dynamically, and the credentials are retrieved from the security material.
  3. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

     

  4. Go to Postman, select the GET method, and paste the endpoint URL.

In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token.

Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1.  Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFLOW

Create/Configure an Integration Flow

  1. Open or create an Integration Flow (iFlow).
  2. Connect the sender participant to Start and select the SFTP as adapter. Configure the SFTP adapter as per requirements.

Make sure that the SFTP credentials are deployed in the below path

Overview --> Manage Security --> Security Material --> Create/Upload Credentials

Check the connectivity test of SFTP adapter in Test Connectivity in the below path

Overview --> Manage Security --> Connectivity Tests --> SSH

Copy the Host Key and paste it in notepad & deploy it in Known Hosts(SSH) file in the below path.

Overview --> Manage Security --> Security Material --> Upload Known Hosts(SSH)

  1.  In the processing tab also configure as per your requirement whether you want to Archive, Keep File and Process Again.

  1. In the scheduler tab also we need to choose how many times this particular interface needs to be run.

  1. Use the CSV to XML Converter to transform the incoming CSV file into structured XML format.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor ‚Üí Message Processing ‚Üí Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

2. PUBLIC KEY :-

 

  • Create SSH KEY :
  1. Go to Monitor > Integrations and APIs, open Manage Keystore, click Create, and select SSH Key to generate a new SSH key.

  1. After creating the SSH key, click on the three dots (Ô∏ô) and select Download Public OpenSSH Key.

Now open the SFTP server. In Windows PowerShell, run the following commands:

  • cd .\Downloads\ ‚Äì to change the directory to Downloads
  • ls ‚Äì to list the files and confirm your SSH key is there
  • cat <your_ssh_key_name>.pub ‚Äì to display the public SSH key

  1. Copy the displayed public SSH key, open the SFTP server, navigate to Public Keys, paste the key, and click Save.

  • SFTP SENDER IFLOW

Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method from username/password to private key.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Public Key' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the user name from the SFTP server.

  1. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

  1. In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token. Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1. Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFLOW
  1. Open the sender SFTP adapter, select 'Public Key' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the user name from the SFTP server.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor ‚Üí Message Processing ‚Üí Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

3. DUAL :-

 

  • SFTP SENDER IFOW

     Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method to Dual.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Dual' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the Credential name.

  1. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

  1. In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token. Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1. Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFOW

      Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method to Dual.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Dual' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the Credential name.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor ‚Üí Message Processing ‚Üí Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

entry.title: [Free Tier] No IAS tenant available when trying to establish trust (SAP BTP)
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm using SAP BTP Free Tier (Pay-as-you-go) and trying to subscribe to services like SAP Build Work Zone and Launchpad.

However, when I try to "Establish Trust" in the subaccount, **no identity Authentication tenant is listed** in the tenant selection.

The screen just shows "No available tenant"

I alreay created an instance of "Cloud Identity Services(default)" in my subaccount. I also received an S-user via email.

Still, I cannot proceed because no IAS tenant is available for selection.

Here ar my details.

- Global Account ID: S0027108224

- Subaccount: dorandev

- Region: AWS South Korea

- Email: doran@doranlab.dev

How can I request or link an IAS tenant for this subaccount? Any help would be appreciated!

Thank you

entry.title: Assistance Required: Issues with SCI Check Process and Virus Scan Warning in SAP
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am new to performing SCI checks in the SAP system and am currently facing an issue. Could someone please guide me through the process of performing SCI checks?

While executing the SCI check, I encountered a warning message: "Cannot Perform inspection: Virus scanner cannot be instantiated: Virus scan profile /SMIM_API/Put is not active." Since it is a warning, I proceeded further, but the results showed that no objects were processed, displaying zero. I have attached a snapshot of the result for your reference.

Could anyone advise on how to resolve this warning and ensure the SCI check processes the objects correctly? Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you,
khaza Mohammad

entry.title: Wildcard usage in App Router routes & XSUAA redirect URIs (Multitenant)
entry.content:
Hi All,

I have developed a multitenant application using the SaaS Registry and successfully deployed it. However, I have a couple of queries regarding the use of wildcard characters in the configuration.

In the xs-security.json file, we have specified redirect URIs to support tenant onboarding without manual intervention. To generalize this, we used the pattern */<domain> for the redirect URIs. I would like to confirm whether this approach aligns with SAP's security policies, or if there is a recommended alternative for handling dynamic redirect URIs across tenants.

Secondly, our application uses the App Router. Currently, we are maintaining individual routes for each tenant subscription. To simplify this, we attempted to define a route using the */<domain> wildcard pattern. However, this does not seem to work as expected. Is there a supported method to configure a single route that applies to all subscribed tenants? Additionally, I would appreciate any guidance on the security implications of using such wildcard patterns in route configurations.

Looking forward to your suggestions and best practices.

Best regards,

Sunil Singireddy.

entry.title: BAS Connection to On-Premises System Failing with 'Request failed with status code 503'
entry.content:
Hello All,

I'm getting a The server returned an error. Request failed with status code 503 in SAP Business Application Studio when trying to connect to an on-premise system.

  • The system is connected successfully in Cloud Connector.

  • Destination is valid, and connection works in Build Apps , Business Automation Process.

  • BAS is the only place it's failing.

  • I have SAP_ALL access, and all required services are accessible as confirmed by  BASIS & SECURITY Team.

Did I miss any configuration on the on-premise system or in BAS? 

Also, is there a way to debug or trace this kind of issue from the BAS or backend side?

 

 

Additional Information:
When I performed the Fiori connection check to trace the issue, I encountered the following errors while establishing the connection in Business Application Studio (BAS):

  • OData V2 catalog service not available.

  • OData V4 catalog service not available.

  • Error: Cannot query V2 catalog service for DEV_001.

  • Error: Cannot query V4 catalog service for DEV_001.

 

 

Destination --> Check Connection

I'm completely new to the BAS application and would appreciate any guidance to help me understand and resolve this connection issue.

entry.title: Switching Cloud Identity tenant in Subaccount Trust Configuration
entry.content:
With OIDC Trusts in a Subaccount to Cloud Identity Services it's possible to switch the Cloud Identity tenant. You can simply edit the config and switch the tenant. User IDs and Authorizations remain untouched - everything works fine.

In the "old" Cloud Identity Tenant it even removes the Application and moves it to the "new" tenant.

Has anyone else used this in a production environment? Is this an official feature that's supported by SAP?

Regards

BTW here is how you can switch a Cloud Identity trust from SAML to OIDC:
Migrate from SAML Trust Configuration to OpenID Connect Trust with SAP Cloud Identity Services | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Evaluating Risks of Non-VPN Access to SAP BTP Cockpit
entry.content:
Hello,

Is it standard practice for users to access the SAP BTP Cockpit using only company-issued S-user credentials‚Äîwithout requiring VPN or corporate network access? While this setup does offer convenience, it also raises potential security concerns. For instance, logging in from a personal device over the public internet, without any corporate network safeguards, could expose sensitive assets.
Would appreciate your thoughts on this. Thanks in advance.

Thanks

entry.title: Best Practice for Storing SAP User Passwords for Communication from BTP to SAP on-premise System
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I need advice on the best practice for storing passwords in an SAP BTP ‚Üí SAP on Prem System communication scenario.

We are not using a technical user setup. Instead, each end user has their own SAP user and password for accessing the backend system. Since we have multiple systems and multiple users per system, I am considering two approaches:

Approach 1:

  • Store the password in a database after encrypting it.

  • Use a unique encryption key for each row.

  • Exclude the password and key fields from the OData service so they are not exposed on the UI.

Approach 2:

  • Store the credentials in the Destination service.

  • For 2 backend systems with 3 users, a total of 6 destinations would need to be created.

Has anyone faced a similar requirement? Which approach would be more secure and scalable? Or is there a better standard way recommended by SAP for handling such a scenario?

Thanks in advance for your guidance!

entry.title: Roles and role collections disappear after deployment
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have been having trouble making role collections for the two applications. When I deploy first  application, the roles and role collections of the second application are deleted and vice versa. Both application are deployed in different spaces of same subaccount. The roles are defined in xs-security of applications. Not sure what exactly is happening. Can you point out what could be the exact root cause?

Regards,

Akshay

 

SAP BTP Security

entry.title: Provision of Sales Cloud V2 APIs via Integration Suite and Cloud Connector for on-prem clients
entry.content:
Dear colleagues,

As part of our ongoing platform transformation, we are migrating to Sales Cloud V2 and S/4HANA. Initial testing within our sandbox environment has confirmed successful access to the Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

For productive use, we aim to establish a secure and scalable integration architecture by leveraging SAP Integration Suite in conjunction with the Cloud Connector. This setup is intended to enable on-premise clients to proactively consume Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

The envisioned scenario involves external calls initiated from on-prem systems, with responses returned from the cloud ‚Äî for example, accessing data related to the Business Partner object.

We would like to validate whether this architecture is technically feasible and aligns with best practices for hybrid connectivity and secure API exposure.

entry.title: Implementing IAS+AMS with BTP Applications
entry.content:
We're implementing IAS+AMS in which the use of XSUAA is eliminated. The implementation goes like this:

1. CAP application with IAS+AMS (separate app)

2. Generate Client ID and Secret in Cloud Identity Service as AMS uses X509 certificate

3. Add a destination for the CAP application with OAuth2UserTokenExchange authentication and using the Client ID and Secret generated

4. Created a Fiori application with managed App Router connected to CAP application via the destination (separate app)

 

The steps followed are here: 

Deploy and Run the Application on Cloud Foundry

[Blog Series] X.509 certificate-based authentication(mTLS) ‚Äì Demystified

 

With this setup, is it possible to totally not use XSUAA? If not, can you help me understand what should be the correct way of implementing IAS+AMS including the destination setup?

entry.title: SAP BTP Trial Establish Trust issue
entry.content:
Hello everyone.

I am currently trying to complete a mission on SAP.com using a trial account. I have created a new trial subaccount and added the SAP Cloud Identity Services. The service appears to be added successfully.

However, when I go to Security ‚Üí Trust Configuration and try to click Establish Trust, I keep getting an error message like the one in the screenshot.

I have already tried the following steps:

  1. Deleted and recreated the trial account.
  2. Added the Cloud Identity Service again.
  3. Created azure instead of amazon.
  4. Repeated the process several times, but the problem remained.

It seems that the subaccount cannot interact properly with IAS (possibly a problem with the tenant registry).

Could you please help me understand why my trial account cannot establish trust?

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: SAP Security Logs Forwarding
entry.content: I want to collect security logs from SAP HANA or SAP Oracle DB for integration with my SEIM. Can SAP HANA logs be accessed or queried directly, and if not, what are the recommended methods to extract or forward SAP security logs securely?

entry.title: HTTP Error: Sending Message- HTTP 400 error
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have a scenario where SAP system is sending message to CPI via XI Proxy and CPI is forwarding this message to 3rd Party via HTTP call. This is synchronous scenario.  Interface is working fine when data is fine. In case of HTTP 500, interface is working fine we have captured the exception message and creating the required response structure and it is going to SAP as expected. 

But when 3rd party is giving HTTP 400 error, in this case CPI is receiving the exception, In CPI we are creating the required response message, but when it is sent to SAP, it is not working as expected. 
Error is shown in SXMB_MONI:

and in the attachment the response is showing as below: 

Thank you.

entry.title: Preparing for SAP C_CPE? Here‚Äôs How I‚Äôm Studying Each Section Without Feeling Overwhelmed
entry.content:
Whenever I start learning something new, I like to have everything in order.
Before I even open the first tutorial, I plan what I‚Äôll study first, what comes next, and how I‚Äôll track it.

Recently, I started preparing for the SAP C_CPE (SAP Certified Associate - Backend Developer - SAP Cloud Application Programming Model) certification. Since this exam covers a mix of BTP architecture, SAP BAS, CAP, Side by side extensions, Cloud Foundry & Kyma Runtime  it can easily feel like too much at once. So I created a simple structure to move step by step without feeling lost.

I began with the learning about BTP, and doing hands on by following SAP Learning Journeys, creating subaccount and adding entitlements and services (It gave me a very clear understanding of BTP architecture) and then Developing appliaction using high productivity tools of SAP BAS, Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) because it‚Äôs the foundation of most topics in this certification. I‚Äôm spending around two weeks learning about CDS models, service layers and how everything connects in a CAP project. I‚Äôm following the official SAP Learning Journey https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-backend-developer-sap-cloud-programming-model and doing small hands-on exercises along the way.

My next focus is Cloud Foundry. I‚Äôll spend about a week learning how to efficiently develop, run, and manage cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime.

After that, I‚Äôll move to Side by side extention on BTP.  This will cover deploying  extension and integrating the app into SAP Build Work Zone.

The next stage is Developing Appliactions in Kyma Environment. I‚Äôll take about two weeks to explore a comprehensive understanding of Kubernetes and to orchestrate the deployment of the applications in the cloud. 

Finally, I‚Äôll study Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK for about two more weeks. These are slightly advanced topics but very useful for understanding to develop and integrate Java, JavaScript, and TypeScript extension applications for SAP solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

So in short, this will be my roadmap-

Recommended Study Sequence

Here‚Äôs the order I suggest, from foundational to more advanced :

  1. Exploring SAP Business Technology Platform 5hrs (link : https://learning.sap.com/courses/exploring-sap-business-technology-platform)
    • This gives you a broad overview of the entire platform (services, architecture, what BTP is). Good for building your base understanding.
    • So start here.
  2. Develop Full‚ÄëStack Applications Using Productivity Tools in SAP Business Application Studio 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-full-stack-applications-using-productivity-tools-in-sap-business-application-studio)
    • Once you know the platform, you learn the developer tooling (BAS = Business Application Studio) which is key for CAP and full-stack apps. 
    • So this is your next step.
  3. Develop Applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime 4hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-on-sap-btp-cloud-foundry-runtime)
    • The Cloud Foundry runtime is a major runtime environment in BTP. Understanding how to build and deploy there is critical. 
  4. Build Side‚Äëby‚ÄëSide Extensions on SAP BTP 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/build-side-by-side-extensions-on-sap-btp)
    • After tooling and platform basics, you dive into extension scenarios (for example side-by-side extensions of S/4HANA using CAP). This aligns closely with CAP certification topics.
  5. Developing Applications in SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime 8hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-in-sap-btp-kyma-runtime)
    • Kyma Runtime is more advanced (Kubernetes, microservices, event-mesh) and often sits on top of foundational knowledge. 
  6. Develop Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK 11hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-advanced-extensions-with-sap-cloud-sdk)
    • This is relatively specialized/advanced (SAP Cloud SDK, perhaps custom libraries, integrations). Once you‚Äôve mastered the fundamentals above, you go here.

By the end of this plan, I‚Äôll go through a short revision period with mock questions and quick notes from my learning.

This structured approach keeps my study plan clear and prevents me from feeling overwhelmed.
I study for two to four hours a day which feels realistic, and the small milestones make it easier to stay consistent.

If you‚Äôre also preparing for C_CPE, it really helps to make your own sequence instead of jumping randomly between topics. The Learning Journeys are excellent resources, but having a personal roadmap makes a big difference.

 

I‚Äôd love to hear how others are preparing for this certification too.
What topics are you finding most challenging so far and how are you managing the learning.

entry.title: IAS-IPS (SAP Security)
entry.content:
IAS & IPS

 

 

Content :

  1. SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)
  2. SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)
  3. Real World Scenario

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)

IAS is SAP‚Äôs cloud-based authentication service.

Its core job is to make sure ‚Äúthe right user logs in securely to the right SAP application.‚Äù

Think of IAS as the gatekeeper.

 

ÔÉ†What IAS Does

  1. Authenticates Users (Login / Sign-in)

IAS verifies user identity when they try to log in to:

  • SAP BTP
  • SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Any custom application connected to IAS

It checks:

  • Username + Password
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (OTP, SMS, Email, Authenticator App)
  • Certificates
  • Biometrics (via device IdP)

 

  1. Single Sign-On (SSO)

IAS supports:

  • SAML 2.0
  • OAuth 2.0
  • OpenID Connect (OIDC)

So your users log in once and access all SAP apps without logging in again.

 

  1. Acts as an Identity Provider (IdP)
  • IAS can serve as

Primary IdP

  • IAS handles authentication directly

Proxy IdP

  • IAS redirects authentication to:
  1. Microsoft Azure AD
  2. ADFS
  3. Okta
  4. Ping Identity
  5. Any SAML-based IdP

IAS becomes the bridge between SAP systems and corporate identity providers.

 

  1. Conditional Authentication Policies

IAS can decide:

  • Who can log in
  • From where
  • Under what conditions

Examples:

  • Allow MFA only when user logs in from outside office
  • Block login from certain countries
  • Force password reset for risky accounts
  • Apply SSO only for trusted devices

 

  1. User Store (Identity Directory)

IAS stores user accounts, including:

  • Username
  • Email
  • First Name / Last Name
  • Groups
  • Password (if local authentication)

Note : BUT IAS does NOT create users automatically ‚Äî IPS usually does provisioning.

 

  1. Authorization Pre-Processing (via Groups ‚Üí Mappings)

IAS can assign groups, and these groups can be mapped in target apps (like SAP BTP) to give role collections.

  • IAS Group = ‚ÄúFinanceUsers‚Äù

‚Üí Mapped to

  • BTP Role Collection = ‚ÄúFinance App Access‚Äù

But IAS itself does NOT assign app roles.

Note : IAS group can only be mapped to BTP role collections, not to PFCG Role etc.

 

  1. Branding & Custom Login Pages

IAS allows full customization of login screens:

  • Company logo
  • Color theme
  • Background
  • Messages
  • Terms & conditions

 

  1. Security Enforcement

IAS applies:

  • Password policies
  • MFA rules
  • Account lockout rules
  • Device trust
  • Risk-based authentication

 

ÔÉ†What IAS Does NOT Do

  • IAS does NOT create users(IPS or external IdP does)
  • IAS group does NOT assign roles in S/4, SAC, Ariba, etc.
  • IAS does NOT do provisioning(IPS does)
  • IAS does NOT perform GRC / SoD checks(IAG does)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

IPS is SAP‚Äôs central user provisioning and synchronization service.

It moves users from one system to another, ensuring that user accounts, attributes, and group/role assignments stay consistent across:

  • SAP BTP
  • IAS (Identity Authentication Service)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Azure AD, Okta, Ping, etc.

Think of IPS as the ‚Äúdelivery service‚Äù for user accounts.

 

ÔÉ†What IPS Does

  1. Creates Users in Target Systems

IPS automatically provisions users into multiple systems.

Example:
SuccessFactors ‚Üí IPS ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí BTP ‚Üí S/4HANA

IPS can create user accounts in:

  • IAS
  • SAP BTP
  • S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP Concur
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (via SCIM)

 

  1. Updates User Attributes

If an employee changes department, email, manager, etc., IPS updates the data in all connected systems.

Example:
SuccessFactors updates ‚Üí IPS sync ‚Üí IAS/BTP/S4/Ariba update

 

  1. Deletes / Deactivates Users

When an employee leaves the company, IPS can mark them inactive or delete their user account.

 

  1. Maps and Transforms Attributes

IPS allows:

  • Attribute mapping
  • Attribute transformation
  • Conditional provisioning

Example:
IF user.department = "Finance" ‚Üí assign group ‚ÄúFIN_USERS‚Äù

 

  1. Assigns Groups / Roles (but not everywhere)

IPS can assign:

  • IAS Groups
  • BTP Role Collections
  • S/4HANA Business Roles
  • SAP Ariba groups
  • SAC roles (via SCIM)

But only where system supports it.

 

  1. Connects to Many Identity Sources

IPS can read users from:

  • Azure AD
  • SuccessFactors
  • IAS
  • LDAP
  • Okta
  • On-premise systems (via Cloud Connector)

What IPS does NOT do

  • IPS does NOT Authenticate Users (IAS does)

 

Real World Scenario

 

 



Company:

A global manufacturing company using:

  • SAP SuccessFactors (HR system of record)
  • SAP BTP (custom apps, Integration Suite)
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud (ERP)
  • SAP Ariba (Procurement)
  • SAP IAS (Authentication)
  • SAP IPS (Provisioning)
  • SAP IAG (Access Governance)

Scenario 1: A New Employee Joins the Company

Step 1 ‚Äî Employee is Hired in SuccessFactors

HR creates a new employee: Rohan Sharma with below details

  • Department: Finance
  • Location: India
  • Manager: Priya Singh
  • Job: Accounts Payable Analyst

SuccessFactors stores all HR attributes.

Step 2 ‚Äî IPS Reads Rohan‚Äôs Data from SuccessFactors

IPS acts as the "provisioning engine."

Flow: SuccessFactors ‚Üí IPS ‚Üí IAS

IPS automatically:

  • Reads new user
  • Maps attributes
  • Creates user in IAS
  • Assigns IAS group ‚ÄúFinance_Employees‚Äù
  • Pushes email, username, and department

Step 3 ‚Äî IAS Creates User Entry + Prepares Authentication

IAS now has user:

  • Username: rohan.sharma
  • Email: rohan.sharma@company.com
  • Group: Finance_Employees
  • Status: Active

IAS does NOT assign roles.

IAS only sets up login policies:

  • MFA required
  • Corporate SSO allowed
  • Conditional rule: India region ‚Üí allow password login

Step 4 ‚Äî IAG Triggers Access Request Workflow

Rohan needs access to:

  • SAP BTP Finance App
  • S/4HANA Finance Business Roles
  • Ariba Buyer Role

In large companies, users cannot get access automatically,they must request access via IAG.

Flow:

  1. Rohan goes to IAG Access Request Portal
  2. Selects: "Finance Analyst Access Package"
  3. Request goes to Manager (Priya Singh)
  4. IAG performs SoD checks ÔÉ† No conflicting roles ÔÉ† No risk
  5. Manager approves

Step 5 ‚Äî IAG Sends Provisioning Action to IPS

After approval:

IAG ‚Üí IPS ‚Üí Target Systems

IPS now provisions the approved roles

  • In SAP BTP: Assigns BTP Role Collection:

Finance_Analyst_RoleCollection

 

  • In S/4HANA Cloud: Assigns Business Roles:

AP_STANDARD

FIN_POSTING

FIN_DISPLAY

 

  • In SAP Ariba: Assigns Ariba group:

Buyer_Professional

 

Step 6 ‚Äî Rohan Logs In to SAP Systems

Rohan logs in to:

SAP BTP App

  • IAS checks login
  • IAS ‚Üí BTP trusts IAS
  • BTP picks up role collection assigned via IPS

S/4HANA Cloud

  • Login route:
  • Browser ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí S/4
  • S/4 checks Business Role assignments provisioned via IPS

Ariba

  • IAS federates login ‚Üí Ariba validates user groups

Step 7 ‚Äî Rohan Changes Department (Employee Movement)

After 1 year, Rohan moves from Finance to Supply Chain.

HR updates this in SuccessFactors.

  • IPS reads update
  • IPS updates IAS + BTP + S/4HANA + Ariba
  • IAG dynamically checks if old roles must be removed.
  • Roles get de-provisioned: Finance roles removed & New Supply Chain roles added

Step 8 ‚Äî Employee Exit

When Rohan leaves company:

  • HR marks employee as terminated in SuccessFactors
  • IPS deactivates him in IAS
  • IPS removes roles in BTP, S/4, Ariba
  • IAS blocks login

User access fully revoked
